reviewText:
This was a very interesting interactive novel in my opinion. It handled the topic at hand with surprising delicacy. The main game is basically Kelly, the protagonist, basically visiting her grandfathers home in the country when the weather turns bad, so she heads home. She and her mom start talking on the phone, and in the midst of the conversation, it is revealed that one or more tornadoes are going to be touching down in the area. So, Kelly must try to get to the safety of home. All the while, she is chatting with her mom, and later with her dad and her brother Ben as well.

It is obvious that she has been estranged from her family and has recently come back to live with them, which has resulted in conflicted feelings and a lot of trying to regain the relationships she once shared.

I wont reveal the ending, but it was both ambiguous and obvious (funny how that works). Through the game, you are basically driving home as mentioned before, and the only knock I have is that you actually have to hold down the D key or (on a gamepad) and trigger.....the entire game, which is annoying. Outside of that however, I thought it was a fairly seamless experience. The dialogue was interesting and the interactions felt real.

There is an epilogue, and this is really where the variant choices and decision come into play (as was highlighted on the product page via the current first page curation (800+ variations). they all take place in the epilogue, and without revealing the actual content (as it would also serve as a spoiler for the main game), I will just say that this was at least as interesting as the main game.

The extras were all cool as well. Ben's stories were all well written and fun to read. Kelly's photo class final was fun to look at, and the soundtrack was excellent.

I give this eight snapshots of a tornado out of ten possible before getting sucked into it because you got waaaaayyyyy too close.

reviewText:
Three Fourths Home, the first visual game by developer [bracket] games, is a beautiful piece of interactive fiction. As a finalist for the IGF’s Excellence in Narrative award, Three Fourths Home is a balancing act between game and story, between driving and speaking, and between truth and fiction. Available for PC and Mac, this game is a worthwhile experience for those who like interactive fiction and branching narrative, but gameplay won’t inspire or challenge many players.
The player, twenty-something Kelly, is on a long drive home. Whatever history you craft for your version of Kelly, it becomes obvious very quickly that she has a strained relationship with her family. Her mother is frequently biting and sarcastic while her father self-medicates; her brother’s mental illness casts a vague but lingering shadow over family interactions. Three Fourths Home doesn’t offer you a lot of answers—almost none, in fact—but it does offer a realistic view of the ways families speak to one another, blending secrets with facts in ways that only make sense to the participants.
The wide Nebraska cornfields provide a unique backdrop for the game. They’re desolate but thriving, unique but plain, a perfect complement to Kelly’s family. And when a storm kicks up and grows in intensity, so do your feelings about the situation. You can’t fix the relationships any more than you can stop the storm—all you can do is keep moving forward, advancing the conversation and hoping you can figure it all out in the end.
Spoiler alert: you can’t. There are some things that can’t be fixed. All you can do is understand; an option the game affords you without forcing it upon you. This is one game where exploring the additional menu options and replaying multiple times will enhance your appreciation of the narrative. While you’ll always come to the same end, each playthrough will help you navigate the conversation a little better, just as reliving a memory will.
The writing in Three Fourths Home is beautiful, although reading the dynamic gray text may strain the eyes a bit at times. The dialog is elegantly crafted and realistic, and Kelly’s brother’s short stories are an excellent way to flesh out the family’s character without using a ham-fisted approach. It encourages the kind of understanding that comes from analyzing a situation after the fact, making it a flawless way to approach the story’s holes and questions.
Three Fourths Home is an interesting example of the interactive fiction/video game divide. While it absolutely has to be a game—the combination of visual, audio, writing, and interactivity require this medium—there’s very little for the player to do.
To advance, you have to hold down either the right arrow or ‘d’ key, otherwise all progression stops. So prepare for some finger cramps. While this mechanic makes sense—forcing you to manage your interactions along with your car progression, just like when you have a conversation while driving—it feels like too little, until it’s too much. As it stands, holding a key down to drive is a tedious way of getting the point across when you’re much more focused on the conversation.
Adding more complications like having to steer or follow directions would definitely complicate the driving, but also distract from the necessarily slow pace. It’s hard to say whether that would be an improvement or just a distraction, but as it is, it treads a very thin line between being too much and too little gameplay, and sometimes feels like it leans too heavily to one side or the other.
Three Fourths Home is a simple game— you can’t lose. But you can’t really win, either. All you can do is see it through to the end and fill in your own ideas about what “success” means in this context. Those who want a traditional game experience with wins, losses, and challenges aren’t going to find it in this game.
There’s a lot to like about Three Fourths Home. It’s the kind of game that makes you think. It’s the kind of game that makes you want to force others to play it so you can talk to them about it, and collectively tap into the moody, melancholic heart of it. It’s a perfect example of using game mechanics to tell a story, while also sometimes stumbling to do it well.If story and interactive fiction interest you, and if you like musing on regret and memory and family, you’ll find something to like in Three Fourths Home.

reviewText: It's not *bad* but it's also not good enough to recommend, especially with so many significantly better story-driven games available (Kentucky Route Zero, 199X, To The Moon, and the Moon Sliver are the ones that come immediately to mind). reviewText:
I do enjoy reading, art, and story-telling in games: Zach Sandford created a pretty cool visual novel. The silohuette art style is cool, but plays a near-passive atmospheric role to the story, as did the background sounds and music. The writing was impeccable and the characters are all unique with the dialogue portraying their personalities very well.

The extra content - short stories, music, and art - is a really nice addition, too.

I have two very minor issues with the game:

1) The grey text on a white background is a little difficult to read
2) My arm started to ache by having to hold down the key to drive (maybe I'm an idiot and didn't see an auto-drive key in the settings?)

Overall, it's really good to see more literature games and I'm glad I spent the £4.50 on it.

reviewText:
I have unique experience while I've playing this game. It has experimental design, minimalist, surreal, have a rich story and very good soundtrack with ambient soundscape within the game. If you like post-rock & experimental music genre, soundtrack of this game can hit you. Eargasm is matter of time after that.

Well, this game is a more story telling than gameplay itself. In main game, the story tell by conversation between Kelly and her family by phone, while she's driving a car in the middle of heavy rain and storm. And for the epilogue, its tell by conversation between Kelly and her mother, while she's waiting for a bus in the middle of snowy day. All choice matter in epilogue, the story can be different because it is depend on what you choose.

One thing that I like in this game is characterization tailored through story. It feels realistic.

If you fan of story rich games, I can recommend this interactive fiction to you.

reviewText: A fantastic narrative experience condensed within an hour. The story tackles on themes of parental obligation, disability, and depression and crafts them into a very real, believable experience. The ambiguity of the story overall makes it very relatable.

reviewText:
Playing this game I fell in love with the characters; the story; the storytelling. Quite simply this is much more about the story than the game. And to me that's not such a bad thing.

The characters are believable, I suppose in part because you get to decide how Kelly should respond and in turn guiding how the other characters repsond. I found myself at times telling her to say what I would say and at other times playing along with the narrative - saying what I think would bring more of the story out for me to hear.

The other part of the believability is how well they're crafted. You don't know their backstory. You get snippets from them. Snippets from other family members. Snippets from Kelly's replies. Enough to make a picture, enough to let your imagination fill in the blanks without thinking the storyteller should have given you more (but wishing they had).

Actually the storytelling is so good I do want more. I want to go back and play it again. Change my answers, try and learn more about everyone. Don't worry, I'm not going to give any spoilers.

So storytelling before gameplay? Yeah that's how this car rolls...through Nebraska...in a storm...but only when holding the buttons down...(play it, you'll see what I mean).

I gotta say, wouldn't you pay such an itty bitty price for an amazingly well crafted and engaging story with believable characters? So why not pay it for a story and game?

reviewText: Three Fourths Musiclistening"3/4 Home is an innovative text-adventure with very simplified b/w graphics. You are a daughter on a longride by car to Minnesota and phoned your Mom. The whole journey you stay in a neverending dialog between her and rest of family. The landscape is changing in the background until the phone connection breaks shortly before the end in a snow blizzard. Now you are waiting for the right bus to take the last leap to home (epilogue). The conversation with your Mom comes to a climax talking out all of your problems.\nTechnically this game is a cheap Unity production. The graphics look horrible and the game concept to drive the longway and keep on talking is poor. I can just praise the richness of dialogues which seem very realistic. But then you realize the raindrops are going through the text and if your car stops also the background sirens stop (wtf?). The decision matrix concentrates just on the epilogue. It's not easy to catch the right bus (which is allegedly 404). Very annoying is to crawl through "extra content" after you reached all endings. Especially the radio listening for about 1 hour was annoying. Not everyone shares the same music taste of Alternative rock / Electronic ..."

reviewText:
I'm fully aware of the fact that Three Fourths Home is more of a narrative experience, and that's fine. I decided to play after hearing Kinda Funny's Colin Moriarty sing praises of it, talking of how sad it was; how thoughtful.
Sorry, it's not.
It was fine at the beginning, but I probably only think that because I thought it was an introduction to something that was more than 40 minutes long. I was thinking I would be playing for about 2 hours, but alas. My fault.
Anyway: the story is pretty darn boring, for starters. I felt little to no emotion. I couldn't care less about the characters. The developers attempted to build and develop the charcters, but in my opinion, utterly failed. There was nothing particularly thought or emotion provoking at all. We only get small details about a family that isn't in the best shape, and that's it. I don't really have much left to say except I was extremely dissapointed.
I do not recommend Three Fourths Home what so ever.

By the way, your finger will be irritated by the end of it all.

reviewText:
6.0/10 – Visual Novel with Intriguing Graphics and Unique Twist!

This game offers a nice twist to the visual novel genre. The story didn't wow me but the gameplay and graphics compelled me enough to enjoy it! You play as Kelly, a girl moving back home to fulfil family obligations. The entire game takes place on the road traversing through 20 miles of storm ridden farmland on the phone. Smart!

You must drive Kelly down the road to trigger the story which takes place via phone conversation with her mom. The story unfolds and concludes in 20-30 minutes which was enough for me. Bonus content unlocks in the form of a playable epilogue. After playing; $5 seems fair based on the length and story graphical intrigue.

Fun side note: 20" seems to be the magic number!!
-Kelly is in her "20's"
-Game takes place over "20" Miles
-Game takes "20" something minutes to complete
-Game was released on March "20th"
- Each Achievement accounts for "20%" 1/5

reviewText: The game only took me about an hour to get through (epilogue included)...it could be that I'm a fast reader. The driving aspect of the game is not as complicated as it sounds...you simply hold in D to keep the story going.  You don't have to worry about dodging traffic or staying on the road.  Frankly it got annoying after a while.  While the story was indeed well done, I don't think that the game warrants a $7 price tag, especially since replayability is practically nil.  I'd give this a go if/when it drops in price, but it won't be for everyone.  I'm giving it a no-recommend based on the price and the content you get for said price.  Buy a Stephen King (or what have you) book that takes days to get through instead.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lJTINhhFI3Q

reviewText:
The wind beat down on her car as the wet road dared to make her rushed driving a dangerous affair. She was Three Fourths Home, talking hurriedly to her mom on the phone - yet it all seemed so far way. She had been gone for a long time. Now that she was back, she wasn't so sure she should be.

Or was she?

Full Review TL;DR at bottom!

Story: It can develop into whatever you wish it to, the different thinks you can say change other people's answers drastically.
Graphics: The well done minimalistic design adds to the atmosphere and makes it easy to focus on what's important: the story.
Music: It's delightful! You can play it while riding through the storm (and I strongly recommend you do) and it's sure to make your ride even more interesting.

Final thoughts: This is a game for casual players. People hoping for gunshots, gore or utter action will bore themselves easily. A game such as this is made to be appreciated by people who are into the genre and who have the patience to make choices and read text. This game is not for everyone, like all games aren't. With that in mind, I strongly recommend it - but with the prospect of not doing so for everyone.

TL;DR: Three Fourths Home is a game about its characters. It's minimalistic in regards of appearance, but deep when considering thoughts, actions and outcomes. It is much like real life, when you can decide to pry, dwell or avoid certain situations and topics. If you like interesting choices, good music and atmosphere and deep thoughts, you are sure to bask in this one's light.

reviewText: Don't play this game expecting it to have enjoyable gameplay. It is an interactive visual novel, where you have to hold the same button for most of the game. If you can get past that however, it tells the story really well, even if it doesn't give much closure. You kind of tell the story, so just know that when it gives you a choice where it feels like it shouldn't, the game is actually giving you the choice of telling the story. I finished the game feeling very confused, but interested in playing more to discover more within the 'game'. It has a really well told narrative, it is just missing the game element. Overall, the sum of the game is better than the individual parts.\n\n70/100

reviewText:
It wasn't very fun, but I didn't expect it to be for a game about those awkward phonecalls to parents. I finished it in about an hour, but it was a bittersweet hour for me.

Three Fourths Home (Extended Edition) comes in two parts. The main story and an epilogue, the latter not being in the initial release. Strangely, the epilogue had a harder emotional impact on me, but even if it didn't, the Extended Edition only costs an extra 2 bucks. Chump change I don't mind giving to have the whole unadulterated experience.

As a story, it's best for those who are currently going through or have recently gone through their coming of age, for it thematically focuses on matters of family and the young adult's fears for the future, stuff not normally dealt with in a medium that is well-known for escapism. So as a game, it's definitely far from the norm, and whether or not that's a good thing will depend on how receptive you are to the idea of reading about the realities of relationships and growing up. Some reviewers think that more games like this are needed. Others think games should just keep being what they've always been about. I think it would be wiser to maintain an open mind when browsing the store page. Opinions are always subject to change as time goes on. The game scorned today for its complete lack of 'gameplay'  might become the game desired for its contextual significance tomorrow. Food for thought.

On a closing note, I have 52 games on this account at the time of writing this. This is the first one I've reviewed, because unlike the others, many of which are excellent, memorable and purchased in good faith and without regret, this one was all that and more for it struck all the right chords within me. So I recommend you buy it and play to the end just to see if it might do the same for you. And if it doesn't, the refund option will still be there, and you'll have only lost an hour. But it'll be an hour in the world of someone who you might just end up becoming one stormy morning.

reviewText: I'm writing this review more based on access for those with limited vision.  This game is nearly unplayable as is with its glaring white background and faint gray dialog.  Then,  as if the faint gray text wasn't bad enough, it slowly faded in and out, making it a headache-inducing experience against the stark white.  Yes, I finally discovered you can make the font a tiny bit bolder in the settings.  The problem is, you can't see there's a dialog tree to choose from underneath the conversations.   If headaches and eyestrain is a fun part of your experience of playing, then this game is for you.

reviewText:
I actually first heard about this game by stumbling upon the devs Kickstarter for their second game, To Azimuth. I backed it just for the game because it looked interesting, but it didn't make it. After playing this game, it's a bigger shame that it failed.

Three Fourths Homes lies more on the interactive fiction side of the adventure game spectrum so if you need to shoot things or stick a rubber duck onto a fishing pole than this isn't for you. Interactive fiction/narrative games live and die on the quality of their writing and I'd say the game delivers. You play as a young woman named Kelly who's returning to her family's farmhouse in Nebraska after not being in contact for some time while a large storm is brewing. Gameplay is simple you just keep driving by holding down a button while you make dialogue choices. Having to hold down a button might be annoying for some but I have to admit I actually stopped noticing that I was doing it and it sort of helped a bit to immerse me more.

Like Kentucky Route Zero and Walking Dead Season 1, the choices you make in the main game are more about shaping who Kelly is and her relationship with her family. The writing is also low key and manages to bring some real humanity and character to the cast that a lot of games struggle with. You get a good feeling for Kelly and her family and you grow to care. The atmosphere is also really good and at some points it can be quite haunting. The ending isn't unpredictable but the epilogue greatly enhances it, really tying together the themes of regret and decay that the game has in a strong way. The Epilogue is the best part of the game because of this and really helps the game to stick with you after its done.

Overall Three Fourths Home is powerful and to the point, a really nice first outing for a fledging dev. I hope the best for them and I'd be willing to back them again if they give To Azimuth another shot. If you like interactive fiction and/or narrative driven games Three Fourths Home is well worth your time and money.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Three Fourths Home: Extended Edition isn’t a game, or a sim, or a visual novel. It isn’t any of the things usually required for an item to be offered by Steam. But it is (in my opinion) two things less commonly found on Steam: a totally inclusive artistic experience, and a detailed work by a writer bursting to express themselves through an emotional outlet involving the player.

It’s an account of a young woman, Kelly, early 20s, talking on the phone to her parents and younger brother, Ben, as she attempts to drive home in the midst of a Nebraska storm, tornado approaching. It’s a family, like any other, with a great deal of love, and lots of issues. It’s very difficult to say much without saying too much, so this will be an unusually short review, with fewer details.

This is the story of a search for self by all participants; characters, players and writer/developer, in no set priority that I can determine. The characters could be kinder toward each other, but in how many families is that generally the case? Everyone in this family has lost something, and throughout, they struggle to regain, or accept the changes that come with loss. Much is expressed through hints and subtle emotion and comments, since only the player is in the dark, and learns certain things through the dialog choices they select during the long conversation over the phone. The existing storm and the approaching tornado add a sense of inevitability, a feeling of the foolishness of man to focus on the minutia of our lives. This game is largely about aspects that may seem petty, but in reality are the very things that consume nearly every moment of our existence. Perhaps ultimately this is about the attempts all humans make to discover themselves through their attempts to discover each other.

One very simple choice I made in this game was so utterly tragic and heartbreaking that I nearly stopped “playing”, for fear continuing would taint the developers intent. I’m very glad I didn’t

Some hints to enjoy this game more completely
Examine the menu option for the game controls. Some are simply there to add a sense of heightened reality. One that I sorely wish I’d known of is the control for playing music in Kelly’s car. The music in this game is one of its strongest features (and that is saying a GREAT deal.) While the music would have added to my game enjoyment, I listen to the music by itself, and enjoy it immensely. Not just the music, but the sounds of the weather add much to the story. Headphones are a strong consideration. (The text is all silent, read from the screen.)
At no point assume this story is over (attempting to exit the game emphasizes this.) Perhaps the presence of achievements, ordinarily a distraction in such a game, may actually serve the purpose of indicating completeness more than accomplishment. Do NOT miss Kelly’s photo essay. And by NO means skip over Ben’s stories. I only hope that some day a game is developed based entirely on these, and similar, atmospheric short stories.

While comparisons to other games, such as Journal, To the Moon or Kentucky Route Zero might be made, this game is far more immersive and artistic than those. Perhaps more than any game that will come along any time soon. If you want to learn something about people and families, and perhaps even something about yourself with a game that does have some degree of replayability, Three Fourths Home is quite possibly the game for you.

reviewText: I never played a narrative story based game like this before. From afar some may think that it is boring" and what not. The story has this ability to suck you in and take hold. Like the first couple pages of your favorite book. Once you start

reviewText:
I suppose my opinion isn't a popular one in regards to Three-Fourths Home but I didn't really enjoy the game.

To begin, I loved the art style, sound effects, music and subtly that the game brought when I first booted it up and started playing. I liked the idea of exploring the characters life and background through dialogue and the minimilistic approach the developer took. However, the game felt like reading someones short-story fiction they submitted to a group critique for an undergrad advanced writing course. I'm not much a fan of visual novels, it's not my cup of tea. This one in particular had some beautiful visual elements that matched where you were in reading the dialogue that added to the mood and really played on your emotions. But, after a while the game just really felt like it was dragging on.

If you like visual novels and are drawn in by character studies, this is a great game for you. It really is designed well and the visuals are fantastic. The writing is very well done as well, but it felt like something that kept going for much longer than it should have.

reviewText: It starts off good. Something different, very unique. Interesting. I didnt connect too much with the characters but thats okay. I was enjoying the ride (literally: the game is your drive home). But then I reached the halfway point. I will not spoil anything but something is injected into the conversation and it feels extremely unnatural. It broke the immersion for me.\n\nWhat was injected wasnt bad. It was kind of interesting. It just did not fit with the game, or what was happening on screen, and after this not so short segment was over I had a hard time figuring out the point of it.

reviewText: When I launched the game for the first time I had no idea what to expect from it. I was just curious. I was surprised by how atmospheric this game is. Sure, it's short but in this short time you can learn about characters and their story. Maybe not entirely; there're some things to wonder about. Which is another charm for this game. If you have the patience and you're willing to listen them out, then you have nothing to lose. You might even get attached to some characters, that's how real they seem. My favorite one is Ben the Benji - protagonist's little bro. I fell in fap, i mean 'love', with his mad writing skills. His stories are darn awesome. I read them holding my breath. That's how cool they are. The Drunkard story is my favorite. I wish there were a blog or something where I could find more of his works. I also simply loved that part of the game when Benji starts telling Kelly a story about the Beast and how they're both so into the story that the sirens and intense thunderstorm suddenly become quiet. And when there's lightning, you can catch a glimpse of the Beast which makes the story even more amazing.\nExtras are delicious, too. Kelly's photo project is fun to check out, the soundtrack is gold and Ben's stories are simply <3 'Nuff said.

reviewText:
Three Fourths Home is an interactive visual novel starring Kelly, a 24 year-old woman who has gone back to her estranged family after several problems in her life: her mother is worried about her but also still feels betrayed by Kelly's past actions, her father lost part of a leg in an accident at work and now drinks when the pain is unbearable while her brother Ben is a shut-in with who still blames her for leaving.
One morning Kelly decides to visit an old barn that belonged to her father and, on the way back, starts having an heart-to-heart phone conversation with her family about their life and her past: a storm starts brewing in and gets worse as you drive home.

PROS:

-remarkable art style

-well-written and emotional story

-great dialogue

-interesting and deep characters

-good pacing, it starts a bit slow but soon things speed up as the weather gets worse

-great soundtrack

-solid sound design

-once you finish the game and epilogue you'll have an Extra section with the whole soundtrack, a few fiction stories written by Kelly's brother and a photo project: they're all very interesting (if you complete" the whole Extras section you'll also be presented with an extra game scene that fleshes out the story)

-provides ample food for thought when played by its target audience


CONS:

-the lack of voice acting slightly lessens the emotional impact

-short at 45ish minutes for the main game plus 15 for the epilogue

-limited replay value

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=487957515

Three Fourths Home was truly an outstanding experience for me
date: it started out a bit slow but as the minutes went by it was easy to connect with Kelly's problems and fears and here lies the game's greatest strength: through its impressive story and storytelling it not only tells a great tale but will also give you quite a few things to think about in regards to life choices
recommended:
missed chances and how one deals with family relationships.

Even if you're not looking for some intellectual nourishment Three Fourths Home sports a story strong enough to be considered a good purchase even if you only take it at face value: the ending was pretty tense and somewhat of a punch in the gut with the powerful epilogue section being equally strong and emotional.

All things considered you might be
voteText: slightly disappointed with the level of interactivity you're given since it all boils down to making a few choices during the dialogue but picking different answers will actually not only give the dialogue itself a different nuance but also shed light on different sides of a character's feelings or a life event. Having said this there's no denying that the dialogue will flow forward on the same path regardless of your choices so here's why the replay value is limited.\n\nThree Fourths Home is a great visual novel with excellent story and writing: a cursory look at online reviews will show you that quite a few people were left pondering on how the story tied with their life long after they stopped playing and this should tell you plenty about its quality. Depending on how much you value "artsy" games and novels it might be overpriced for what it does but if you see it on sale or
votesHelpful: in a bundle pick it up

reviewText: If you don't like interactive game/novels with lots of reading this won't be for you. If you do however like games like kentucky route zero, gone home, etc. then you will most likely enjoy this story of a girl and her relationship with her family and lifes struggles.  The game itself well i'm not sure why they even have you control the driving and walking other than just stop and go. Sometimes you can inadvertantly pick dialogue choices which there are a plenty.  The story is well written getting very deep and emotional/personal througout.   Also the music sets the vibe extremely well and the extras section includes an impressive soundtrack. The extras also have more short stories by the games writer/designer and even a photography section.  Short game but moving and exceptional art.  Wouldn't rank it as high as some of the others in the genre but still well above average though for those who don't love the genre I would wait for a sale.  Got this one as part of a greenlight bundle.  Will toss the dev some money for the extra art book and soundtrack at some point as the music is mighty fine.

reviewText: A hard-hitting interactive story about the choices we make and the consequences of those actions. Driving home in a storm, Kelly has an extended chat with her family. If you like Actual Sunlight, Gone Home or Kentucky Route Zero, this is one for you.

reviewText: This is less of a game and more of an interactive story/art project. There is no intense gameplay, there are no intense puzzles, just the story, art, and music. The minimalist visuals and atmospheric soundtrack do well to not only give the narrative proper focus, but also reflect its scale. Three Fourths Home is a peek at the life of a young woman and her family, and it explores family and life issues in a tasteful, realistic manner. Its subtlety fleshes out emotions well in the first part of the game, and while the epilogue felt a bit heavy-handed and harsh at first, it was brought back down to Earth with its climax. Not all the characters are likeable, but that reflects the reality behind the story. The extra content is also a nice touch, fleshing out the world further and giving the feeling that the family's story goes beyond the main narrative. Overall, it is beautiful, subtle, and emotional, and while it's hard to recommend it as a game, it is easy to recommend as an experience.

reviewText: Three Fourths Home: Extended Edition is a character study. You learn about Kelly, her family, and the trials that have led to this place and time. Kelly is trying to get in home in the middle of a summer storm in Nebraska. While driving she is talking to first her mother and then the other members of her family. The interactive comes in the form of selecting how Kelly responds during the conversation.\n\nIf you are looking for a game with a lot of interactivity, this game is not for you. But I suspect anyone reading this would know that already. If the general descriptions of the game have piqued your interest, then the game is worth your time and money. With that said, make sure you play the second scenario (Kelly waiting for the bus in Minnesota) to get the full sense of the game. Also, the stories that are included as extras are worth your time as well.

reviewText:
Three Fourths Home isn't a game about coming home and not wanting to be there. Three Fourths Home is a game about holding right.

Three Fourths Home is a tight little (emphasis on the little) visual novel about post-college woman who comes home and doesn't want to be there. As someone who typically loves the not-video game genre with things like Gone Home and the Beginners Guide this is probably the first time I ever questioned where a game like this was worth the purchase.

The visuals are actually interesting even if they are a little static and the sound design is spot-on, placing you in a car ride during a rain storm but it's actually the narrative that was the biggest let down of the game. The subject of having to return from school, back to a small town and back to living with your parents is a story that's becoming more and more real for a lot of people and something video games haven't really tackled. And the portrayal of this feels honest. There's a contrained politeness from the main character when she's talking to her mom and dad but that's where it ends. The story's told through a series of phone calls between the main character and her family but it feels limited and constrained. Characters can only really stress how dangerous a storm is until it gets VERY stale and where we're meant to read into what's not being said and extrapolate and think about the situations, what we find feels shallow and a little predictable.

reviewText: If you liked Kentucky Route Zero, you'll almost definitely like this, since it has a similar atmosphere and weaves player choice into the narrative in the same way. Great writing, too—just realize that it's more of an interactive novel than a traditional video game. That's not really a criticism, but I feel like a lot of the negative reviews come from people who didn't really know what they were buying. I feel like it's a little overpriced for the length (both the main story and epilogue took me a little under an hour), but I'm a fast reader, so it'll probably last most people a bit longer. The white background also hurt my eyes after a while; the epilogue was a lot easier to read because of the darker background. Overall, I'd highly recommend Three-Fourths Home. It's one of those games that will stick with you for a while.

reviewText:
Three Fourths Home feels less like a video game and more like a lightly interactive play. As such, it isn't for everyone - but if that premise interests you then I recommend it. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

It's essentially a discourse between a small cast of characters. The player can navigate the conversation at their leisure, branching occasionally. The dialogue has to be strong for this to work - and it is: strong enough that it would probably transpose very well to the stage. This feeling is helped by its minimal aesthetic and atmospheric soundtrack. It boils down to a humble, human story about family and life and stuff. It is beautiful.

I played through once, which took me about an hour (including the epilogue - which isn't really an epilogue at all, it's a critical second chapter which fills out the plot. Don't skip it). I may go back and explore the fringes of the story, as the achievements suggest that there is more to be discovered.

reviewText: It is hard to call this game a real game. It is a short story, but you don' t read the text from pages like you do with a book, but participate in narration listening to the ambient sounds around you, seeing your surroundings (albeit minimalistic, but your imagination can do the rest) and chosing the conversation lines. It's a good way for story-telling of the 21st century to develop, allowing deeper immersion into the story and the character (which, if printed, would have been just an ordinary dialog), and I hope the developers will use this experiment as a groundwork for their future projects.

reviewText:
Have you ever wondered how would it be like to be all alone, all being shattered around you? Imagined how a simple conversation could turn into something so... intense that you would not like to talk about your problems, but still want to?

This game is more of a visual story. Being said that, I enjoyed this piece of work and loved it. The soundtrack is so good!
The minimalistic way of putting it, the design and concept of the game, the way the story moves on from one part to the other one, just good. I literally got goosebumps in the end of the original story.

Overall, 9/10.

Also, get the deluxe edition if you can. Worth it.

PS: You would be disappointed if you would see this as a game.

reviewText: I wish I could give this game neutral feedback, but as a fan of the genre (visual novels/short stories), I feel like I can give it a slightly positive review.  The game is very brief, which is fine, and consists of two telephone conversations (one during the main game, and one during the epilogue) with the protagonist's mother.  The conversation itself feels mostly authentic, but I was slightly distracted by the fact that the mother keeps simulataneously telling your character to be careful driving in the bad weather, but refusing to get off of the phone.  That is a minor complaint, but the bigger problem is that the story doesn't really go anywhere.  The Epilogue is a bit better than the main game, in my opinion, and I do like the very simple art style.  If you enjoy story-based games, and can catch this on sale, I would say it's worth checking out.  It's clear that quite a bit of care went into the crafting of the experience.
